Description: Terracotta wine amphora stopper. Central nipple for lifting with concentric circkles and radial lines. Mould-made. Fine orange-brown clay with buff surface.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Similar forms are found in the western Mediterranean towards the end of the Roman Republican period and from the Roman Western provinces. This type of stopper (Thomas 2011: Type 3A; Hesnard & Gianfrotta: 82-5 Type 3A) and similar types have been found on the 50BC Saint-Gervais 1 wreck in Fos-sur-Mer, just west of Marseille in France, as well as the Roman sites of Magdalensberg in Austria and Unión near Cartagena in Spain. Examples from Ephesus come from Lamboglia 2 and Dressel 6A amphorae, probably from the Adriatic coast of Italy as well as from Egypt (Tamas Bezeczky pers. comm. and forthcoming). Inclusions and colour suggest Mareotis, Alexandria as place of production, though an unusually fine example. Similar mould made stoppers were made in Alexandria during the Augustan period and have been found in wrecks off Alexandria harbour dating to the first century BC (Thomas 2011) and were not found in later contexts on the Red Sea (Ibid.). No examples have been found at the Mareotis amphora kilns, though the fabric is the same, suggesting they were made at a different location nearby (Tomber & Thomas 2011). Bailey, D., 2007.
